According to sources, several industries such as restaurants, factories, and supermarkets have been identified as high-risk areas where the spread of the virus is rampant. Despite several warnings, workers are forced to work in close proximity to each other and customers, increasing the risk of infection. To address this, a committee of workers and management has been formed to identify these scenarios and recommend suitable interventions. The committee has recommended the use of appropriate combinations of controls following the hierarchy of controls to limit the spread of COVID-19. The first control measure recommended is engineering controls such as the installation of physical barriers between workers and customers. Additionally, the use of contactless payment methods and curbside pickup can also be employed to reduce contact between workers and customers. Administrative controls such as staggering work schedules and implementing shift rotations have also been suggested. This would reduce the number of workers present in the workplace at any given time, reducing the risk of transmission. Lastly, personal protective equipment (PPE) such as masks and gloves have been recommended for workers who are unable to maintain social distancing. Employers have a responsibility to provide adequate PPE to their workers and ensure that they are using them correctly. While protecting workers is of utmost importance, it is equally essential to note that control recommendations or interventions to reduce the risk of COVID-19 are necessary to protect customers as well. It is high time that employers take the necessary measures to protect their workers and customers during these unprecedented times. Failure to do so could result in an outbreak in the workplace, putting the lives of countless individuals at risk.
